slides.setup_instructions: Print the 'I Have a Dream' excerpt at appropriate reading level. Gather photographs of the March on Washington showing the crowd size and diverse participants. Have the rhetorical techniques chart from language class available.

slides.text: The March on Washington was not one person's idea — it was a coalition of civil rights organizations working together. A. Philip Randolph, a labor leader, first proposed a march in 1941. By 1963, the time was right, and six major organizations joined forces.

On August 28, 1963, approximately 250,000 people of all races gathered at the Lincoln Memorial. It was the largest demonstration in Washington's history at that time. The march demanded jobs and freedom — economic justice alongside civil rights.

Read Dr. King's words: 'I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.' Notice the techniques: repetition of 'I have a dream,' references to the Declaration of Independence, vivid metaphors.

The march pressured Congress to act. Less than a year later, President Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, banning discrimination in public places and employment. The Voting Rights Act followed in 1965. Organized, peaceful mass action produced real legislative change.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Annotate the 'I Have a Dream' excerpt identifying at least 5 rhetorical techniques (repetition, metaphor, allusion, etc.). Connect this to your language arts study of persuasive techniques. (2) Write your own 'I Have a Dream' paragraph about an issue you care about, using at least three of Dr. King's techniques. (3) Add the March on Washington, Civil Rights Act, and Voting Rights Act to your timeline.

slides.text: The March on Washington shows the power of coalition-building and peaceful demonstration. Dr. King's speech remains one of the most famous in history because of its powerful vision of equality. Next week, we will examine how the movement continued beyond these landmark achievements.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the significance of the March on Washington, analyze rhetorical techniques in Dr. King's speech, and connect the march to subsequent legislation?

parent_notes: This lesson connects beautifully to language arts through rhetorical analysis. Dr. King's speech uses the same persuasive techniques students studied earlier: ethos, pathos, logos, repetition, and metaphor. Having your child listen to the speech recording brings the text alive in ways that reading alone cannot. The 'I Have a Dream' writing activity encourages children to connect civil rights ideals to issues they personally care about, making history relevant and personal. This is also a good opportunity to discuss how change happens through organized, persistent effort.

title: Symbiotic Relationships in Ecosystems
description: Students investigate the three types of symbiotic relationships: mutualism, commensalism, and parasitism. They analyze real-world examples, classify relationships, and design an experiment to observe a symbiotic relationship in their local environment.
instructions:
1. Review how organisms interact within ecosystems (competition, predation, symbiosis).
2. Define symbiosis as a close, long-term relationship between two different species.
3. Introduce mutualism: both species benefit (clownfish and anemone).
4. Introduce commensalism: one benefits, the other is unaffected (barnacles on whales).
5. Introduce parasitism: one benefits, the other is harmed (ticks on deer).
6. Classify ten example relationships into the three categories.
7. Discuss why symbiotic relationships are important for ecosystem stability.
8. Examine how human activity disrupts symbiotic relationships.
9. Students research one symbiotic relationship in depth.
10. Design an observation plan for finding symbiosis in the local environment.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare cards with symbiotic relationship examples and images. Include a mix of all three types with varying difficulty. Gather reference materials for independent research.

slides.text: Symbiosis means 'living together.' It describes any close, long-term relationship between two different species. There are three types based on whether each species benefits, is harmed, or is unaffected.

MUTUALISM: Both species benefit. Example: Bees and flowers. Bees get nectar (food), flowers get pollinated (reproduction). Another example: Clownfish and sea anemones. The clownfish gets protection, the anemone gets cleaned and defended.

COMMENSALISM: One species benefits, the other is neither helped nor harmed. Example: Barnacles on a whale. Barnacles get free transportation to food-rich waters. The whale is unaffected. Another: Birds nesting in trees.

PARASITISM: One species benefits at the other's expense. Example: Ticks feed on deer blood, weakening the deer. Tapeworms live inside host animals, stealing nutrients. Parasites rarely kill their hosts — a dead host means no more food.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Sort the 10 symbiosis example cards into mutualism, commensalism, and parasitism. For each, explain your reasoning. (2) Research one symbiotic relationship in depth and create a mini-poster showing: the two species, how they interact, which type of symbiosis it is, and what would happen if the relationship was disrupted. (3) Go outside with a magnifying glass and observe for 10 minutes. Can you find any symbiotic relationships in your local environment? Record observations in your journal.

slides.text: Symbiotic relationships show us that ecosystems are built on connections between species. When we damage one species, we affect its partners too. This interconnection is why conservation must consider entire ecosystems, not just individual species.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define and distinguish the three types of symbiosis, classify real-world examples, and identify potential symbiotic relationships in their local environment?

parent_notes: Symbiosis is a fascinating topic that helps children see the natural world as a web of relationships. The outdoor observation activity is particularly valuable — look for lichen on trees (fungus + algae mutualism), bees on flowers, birds following lawnmowers for insects, or moss on rocks. If your child has pets, discuss the human-pet relationship — is it mutualism? The classification activity develops logical thinking as students must analyze who benefits and who is harmed in each relationship. This connects to the broader ecology theme of interconnection.

title: Documentary Photography — Telling Stories with Images
description: Students learn the art of documentary photography, which captures real life to tell stories and raise awareness about social and environmental issues. They study the work of documentary photographers, learn composition techniques, and create a photo essay on a local environmental topic.
instructions:
1. Define documentary photography: capturing real moments to tell a story or raise awareness.
2. Examine the work of Dorothea Lange (Great Depression), Sebastiao Salgado (environment), and modern photojournalists.
3. Discuss the ethics of documentary photography: consent, representation, truth.
4. Teach composition techniques: rule of thirds, leading lines, framing, perspective.
5. Discuss how captions and sequencing create narrative in a photo essay.
6. Students choose a local environmental topic for their photo essay.
7. Plan a shot list: What images will tell the story?
8. Go on a photography walk to capture images.
9. Select and sequence the best 5-8 images.
10. Write captions that add context and meaning to each photograph.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather examples of documentary photography appropriate for the age group. Prepare composition guide with rule of thirds grid. Charge cameras or tablets. Print photo essay planning templates.

slides.text: Documentary photography captures real life — not posed or staged. It tells stories, preserves history, and can inspire action. Dorothea Lange's Depression-era photographs helped pass laws to help migrant workers. Images have power.

Composition makes the difference between a snapshot and a photograph. RULE OF THIRDS: Imagine your frame divided into a 3x3 grid. Place key subjects along the lines or at intersections. LEADING LINES: Use paths, fences, or rivers to guide the viewer's eye.

Ethics matter: Always ask permission before photographing people. Represent your subject honestly — do not manipulate images to change the story. Your goal is truth, not drama. A good documentary photographer respects their subjects.

A photo essay is a series of photographs that tell a story together. Like a written essay, it has a beginning (establishing shot), middle (details and evidence), and end (closing image). Captions provide context the image alone cannot convey.

slides.prompt: Create a photo essay on a local environmental topic (a park, garden, stream, construction site, recycling center, or your own yard). Plan your shot list first: What story do you want to tell? Take at least 15 photographs using composition techniques. Select your best 5-8 images and arrange them in narrative order. Write a caption for each photo (1-2 sentences) that adds information beyond what the viewer can see. Give your photo essay a title.

slides.text: Documentary photography combines artistic vision with social purpose. Your photo essays document something real about your environment and your perspective. Share them with your family and discuss: What story did you choose to tell, and why?
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply composition techniques, create a coherent photo essay with narrative structure, and write informative captions?

parent_notes: Documentary photography is a powerful medium for developing visual literacy, critical thinking, and environmental awareness. The composition techniques (rule of thirds, leading lines) apply to all photography and visual art. The ethics discussion is age-appropriate and important — children should learn to be thoughtful about how they represent others. If your child does not have access to a camera, a smartphone works perfectly. Consider displaying their photo essay at home or sharing it with family as a finished artistic work.
